bioghist.p: As a teacher, lecturer, curator and writer, Stella Kramrisch (1898-1993) devoted nearly 70 years to the study and appreciation of Indian art. In remembering Kramrisch, Thomas Lawton, the former deputy director of the Freer Gallery of Art, observed that "all students of Indian culture must acknowledge an intellectual indebtedness" to Kramrisch's numerous and highly original scholarly contributions. Stella Kramrisch was born May 29, 1898 in the Moravian town of Nikolsburg (now Mikulov), Austria. When she was about ten years old, her family moved to Vienna. Her early years of education there included Greek, Latin and German philosophy, which introduced her to Indian literature. At the University of Vienna, Kramrisch complimented her studies in art history with courses on Sanskrit, and with the completion of her dissertation on early Buddhist sculpture in India, she received her doctoral degree in 1919. That same year, Kramrisch was invited to lecture at Oxford University. While in England, she met the Bengali writer and philosopher Rabindranath Tagore, who was Asia's first Noble laureate, having received the Noble Prize in literature in 1913. At that time, Tagore was involved in establishing an international university that would bring together scholars from East and West cultures. The university, which is known today as Visva Bharati, was located in the town of Santiniketan in West Bengal, India, and Tagore invited Kramrisch to come there to teach at Kala Bhavan, the university's College of Fine Arts and Crafts. Accepting the offer, Kramrisch sailed to India in 1920 and taught Indian art and a survey of Western art at the college. In 1923 she left Bengal and joined the faculty at the University of Calcutta, becoming its first professor of Indian Art. The following year, Kramrisch published her first book, "Principles of Indian Art," (translated from German), which contemporary major scholars praised highly. Although Kramrisch continued to teach for the next 17 years in Calcutta, she spent part of each year from 1937 to 1940 in London lecturing at the Courtauld Institute. Leaving Calcutta in 1950, Kramrisch came to the United States to join the faculty of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia as a Professor of South Asian Art, and she continued to teach there until 1969. (It is unclear whether her departure from India also may have been precipitated by the assassination of her husband that same year in Pakistan). In 1954 Kramrisch also took on the role of curator of Indian art at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and served as such until 1972. From 1972 until her death in 1993, Kramrisch oversaw the department as Curator Emeritus. Undaunted by the academic and curatorial demands made of her in Philadelphia, Kramrisch also accepted an appointment at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, and taught as a Professor of Indian Art from 1964 to 1982. As noted in the PMA's published memorial, Kramrisch's writings were even more far-reaching as many of her books continue to be used in universities around the world. During her tenure at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Kramrisch developed its holdings in Indian and Himalayan art and staged a series of ambitious exhibitions that, accompanied by the catalogues and related studies that she wrote, brought significant recognition to the Museum and to the field of Indian art and culture. One such exhibition opened in 1968. Entitled "Unknown India: Ritual Art in Tribe and Village," it showcased nearly 500 religious and secular objects. After 12 years of planning, research and negotiations, another ground-breaking exhibition, "Manifestations of Shiva" opened in 1981. It was the first major exhibition in this country to examine the religious deity and to explore the multiple interpretations of its meaning. Many of the 197 objects displayed had never before left India. As to the Museum's own collection, Kramrisch oversaw important acquisitions, including a 6th century bronze mask of Shiva, a bronze figure of Rama made during the Chola dynasty of southern India, and "Radha and Krishna," a painting by a Kishangarh school artist. Kramrisch received worldwide recognition for her many achievements, including honorary degrees from Visva Bharati University (1974) and from the University of Pennsylvania (1981). At a ceremony held at PMA in 1979, Kramrisch was given the Austrian Cross of Honor for Science and Art, and in 1985 she received the Freer Medal for her contribution to the "understanding of Oriental civilization as reflected in their arts." Perhaps the most telling testament of Kramrisch's life's work came in 1982 when the Indian government presented her with its highest civilian honor of Padma Bhushan. Kramrisch received the honor for "stimulating a renewed interest not only in the artistic heritage of India but also in its underlying philosophies and world view." Stella Kramrisch died on August 31, 1993, at the age of 97.

scopecontent.p: With most of the material pertaining to her research, writings and reference files, the papers of Stella Kramrisch underscore her lifelong commitment to the study and appreciation of Indian art. The first series, "Personal papers and records," consists of two subseries that divide documentation by material type and by subject. The few files of correspondence pertain primarily to a fellowship and letters of recommendation. Other material types include business cards, personal stationary, a rolodex file and a photograph album/scrapbook, which is the most revealing item of Kramrisch's personal life and interests. The album contains clippings, correspondence and other papers in addition to photographs that include images of Kramrisch as a young woman in India and of her cat. The album was compiled by Kramrisch's administrative assistant for a biographical project that was never published. Two of the subjects documented in the second subseries are posthumous matters, namely her estate and memorial. Other subjects are honors and awards, insurance, and travel. The second series pertains to Kramrisch's personal art collection, and includes documentation of objects she gave to the Museum as gifts, loans and bequests. Objects include Indian and Tibetan paintings, sculptures and books, as well as rugs, jewelry and textiles and non-Indian objects, such as 19th century American metalwork and hooked rugs. Documentation includes photographs, inventories and appraisal lists. The material of Series 3, "Curatorial and teaching positions," pertains to Kramrisch's appointments to the Philadelphia Museum of Art and to the University of Pennsylvania, and to lectures she gave throughout the country from the mid-1950s to mid-1980s. The museum files include the press release about her death and some posthumous correspondence. Series 4, "Writings and research," pertains to books and articles Kramrisch wrote as well as a few items that remained unpublished. The documentation of The Presence of Siva is extensive and consists of manuscripts, proofs and reviews as well as some correspondence, research and information regarding copyright registration and photographers. The book was published by Oxford University Press in 1981 to coincide with the major PMA exhibition curated by Kramrisch, "Manifestations of Shiva." There are also several files to some of Kramrisch's earliest writings, such as a 1921 work entitled, "The representation of nature in early Buddhist sculpture," and dating from 1940-1941, "The hundred verses of Amaru illustrated," and "The drawings of Rabindranath Tagore." Materials Kramrisch compiled apparently for general reference comprise the final series and include index cards, photographs, color transparencies, glass negatives, lantern slides, and microfilm. Many of the images are of Indian temples. Other materials in the Kramrisch papers include a processed collection of research notes, manuscripts, photographs, color transparencies, glass and plastic slides, and some correspondence. These materials are related to books, papers, and articles by Kramrisch. A majority of the materials appear to be related to The Hindu Temple, published in Calcutta in 1946. There are also materials related to Indian Sculpture and the Presence of Siva and to articles, forwards, and reviews. There are also research notes for an unfinished book on death that Kramrisch had planned to co-author with Anindita Balsev and notes for what appears to be an unfinished work on the numerology and cosmology of the ancient world. This portion of the Kramrisch papers also includes clippings, articles and reviews by others scholars, and translations of various Puranas and Vedic texts by S.K. Pidara and other unidentified translators. Among the Kramrisch papers held by the Museum, there are materials that have yet to be processed, including research notes, manuscripts, reprints, correspondence, and photographs. The research materials in this portion of the collection consist of notebooks containing Kramrisch’s handwritten notes on readings and descriptions of sites and objects. Manuscript material includes reviews and articles written by Kramrisch, including drafts of her article for the Encyclopedia Americana on the Architecture and Art of India. There are numerous reprints, articles, lecture notes and reviews by other scholars, as well as some by Kramrisch. Many of the reprints are inscribed by their authors. There is professional correspondence in this portion of the collection relating to writings and scholarship by Kramrisch and by others. There is also a series of postcards sent to Kramrisch from her friend Helen Drutt. Photographic material in this portion of the collection includes prints and negatives of Indian and Nepalese sculpture, architecture, and painting. Other items in this portion of the collection include records of a photography project in Bharhut, 1981-1985; an inventory of Kramrisch’s collection of Eastern India metalwork, 1998; reel-to-reel audio recordings of lectures given by Kramrisch, including a 1963 lecture on Indian sculpture; certificates, diplomas, and plaques awarded to Kramrisch; newsletters from the American Committee for South Asian Art, 1974-1990; and printouts from the PMA project to catalog Kramrisch's library in 1995.
